text: Our Government continues to have Australians backs as we all fight through the impacts of #COVID19. The situation we‚Äôre facing is unpredictable but this is about delivering the support Australians need and the policies our economy requires to reopen, recover and create jobs.
These supports are a lifeline but our #JobMaker plan is also setting Australia up for our country‚Äôs recovery. Our focus remains on reopening the economy where it is safe to do so.

#JobKeeper will be extended by six months to the end of March next year and the temporary supplement for those on income support will also be extended until the end of the year, we‚Äôve just announced #auspol #breaking https://t.co/QfA4lLte0Y
Our Government remains resolute in holding those responsible to account. We will never forget that terrible day and stand firm for the justice the victims and their loved ones deserve.

We‚Äôre also increasing the instant asset write off threshold from $30,000 to $150,000 and expanding access to include businesses with annual turnover of less than $500 million (up from $50 million) until 30 June 2020.

Labor had 6 yrs in Govt to remove GST on sanitary items & did nothing. They promised to do it before the last election & reversed that promise before the election was held. Labor always wants you to judge them on what they say & promise, not what they do. We just get on with it.

Over the next 4 yrs states and territories will receive an additional $6.5b in GST revenue because of changes we have made to improve the integrity of the tax system. Agreeing to remove GST from sanitary items is a modest change and totally doable from a financial perspective.

It is a practical issue. There‚Äôs no great gender conspiracy. It‚Äôs just a tax anomaly that can be fixed if all the states agree.

Sure, there are much bigger issues - the drought, electricity prices, jobs - just to name a few. But that doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt deal with this as well.

Three years ago Joe Hockey asked State and Territory Treasurers to remove the GST from sanitary products. They didn‚Äôt agree. We have decided to give this another go so in June I wrote to them to ask them again.  This time, I hope they agree.
